abstract.p: Letter from Pam Baker (Environmental Defense), commenting on June 1 article on plight of sea turtles, says shrimp boats must be kept to deep water in order to protect Kemp's ridley sea turtle in Gulf of Mexico

block.p: ''Sea Turtles Nearing Extinction in Pacific, Study Says'' (news article, June 1) underscores the broad plight of sea turtles. Unfortunately, the leatherback is just one of several sea turtles on the endangered list.

In the Gulf of Mexico, the Kemp's ridley sea turtle continues to fight for its existence. While protection of nesting beaches has stopped egg poaching, accidental capture by shrimpers remains a problem. So far this year, 42 Kemp's ridley turtles have washed ashore on Texas beaches.

''Sea Turtles Nearing Extinction in Pacific, Study Says'' (news article, June 1) underscores the broad plight of sea turtles. Unfortunately, the leatherback is just one of several sea turtles on the endangered list.

In the Gulf of Mexico, the Kemp's ridley sea turtle continues to fight for its existence. While protection of nesting beaches has stopped egg poaching, accidental capture by shrimpers remains a problem. So far this year, 42 Kemp's ridley turtles have washed ashore on Texas beaches.

There is a way to protect these turtles while benefiting shrimpers. By moving shrimp boats to deep water, away from the turtles' shallow mating and nesting ground, we can protect sea turtles and spawning white shrimp that share the turtle's mating area.
PAM BAKER Corpus Christi, Tex., June 5, 2000
The writer is a fisheries biologist for Environmental Defense, a public interest group.
